title: Academic IELTS Reading Test 09
content: Complete IELTS Academic Reading Test 9 with three passages and 40 questions

questions.instructions:
Do the following statements agree with the information given in Reading Passage 1?

In boxes 1 – 6 on your answer sheet write

TRUE if the statement agrees with the information
FALSE if the statement contradicts the information
NOT GIVEN if there is no information on this in the passage
questions.question: Potential tenants must undergo a selection process that takes into account more than finances.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. The first paragraph states '…with its residents' cooperative board deciding on the eligibility and suitability of prospective tenants with a view to maintaining the building's unique character, traditions and atmosphere.'

mc_options.feedback: Correct! The first paragraph states '…with its residents' cooperative board deciding on the eligibility and suitability of prospective tenants with a view to maintaining the building's unique character, traditions and atmosphere.'

Incorrect. Review the first paragraph which mentions that the residents' cooperative board decides on the eligibility and suitability of prospective tenants to maintain the building's unique character, traditions and atmosphere.

Incorrect. Review the first paragraph which mentions that the residents' cooperative board decides on the eligibility and suitability of prospective tenants to maintain the building's unique character, traditions and atmosphere.

questions.question: The Dakota building was built in a heavily populated area in order to draw on the number of people there.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is FALSE. The second paragraph states '…when the Dakota was built, the upper West Side of New York was relatively uninhabited…'.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The second paragraph clearly states that when the Dakota was built, the upper West Side of New York was relatively uninhabited.
Correct! The second paragraph states '…when the Dakota was built, the upper West Side of New York was relatively uninhabited…'.
Incorrect. The second paragraph clearly states that when the Dakota was built, the upper West Side of New York was relatively uninhabited.

questions.question: The original Dakota apartments were not intended for the wealthy upper class.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. The second paragraph contains the phrase [The apartments were] 'not originally for the mega-wealthy…'

mc_options.feedback: Correct! The second paragraph contains the phrase [The apartments were] 'not originally for the mega-wealthy…'
Incorrect. Review the second paragraph which discusses the original target residents and mentions they were not for the mega-wealthy.
Incorrect. Review the second paragraph which discusses the original target residents and mentions they were not for the mega-wealthy.

questions.question: The reasons behind the naming of the Dakota are disputed.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. The third paragraph starts '…It has long been held, though also contradicted, that the name 'Dakota' was chosen because…'

mc_options.feedback: Correct! The third paragraph starts '…It has long been held, though also contradicted, that the name 'Dakota' was chosen because…'
Incorrect. The third paragraph indicates there is debate about the naming, using the phrase 'though also contradicted' regarding theories.
Incorrect. The third paragraph indicates there is debate about the naming, using the phrase 'though also contradicted' regarding theories.

questions.question: The gardens and tennis courts were designed to be used exclusively by the residents.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is NOT GIVEN. The fourth paragraph mentions gardens and tennis courts but there is no mention of whether these were exclusively for the residents.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While the fourth paragraph mentions these facilities, it does not specify whether they were exclusively for residents or not.
Incorrect. While the fourth paragraph mentions these facilities, it does not specify whether they were exclusively for residents or not.
Correct! The fourth paragraph mentions gardens and tennis courts but there is no mention of whether these were exclusively for the residents.

questions.question: The apartments are all designed differently.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. The fifth paragraph states that '…no two apartments are alike…'.

mc_options.feedback: Correct! The fifth paragraph states that '…no two apartments are alike…'.
Incorrect. The fifth paragraph clearly states that no two apartments are alike, meaning they differ.
Incorrect. The fifth paragraph clearly states that no two apartments are alike, meaning they differ.

questions.instructions: Choose the appropriate letter A – D and write them in boxes 12 – 13 on your answer sheet.
questions.question: When the building changed from rentals to an ownership scheme,
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is C. The sixth paragraph states '…a benefactor was approached who bought the apartment on behalf of the resident couple and allowed them to stay on.'

mc_options.text: the residents were able to make huge profits.
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While one apartment later sold for a profit, the passage does not say that all residents made huge profits.

mc_options.text: investors approached the tenants to buy their apartments.
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The passage does not mention that investors approached tenants to buy apartments.

mc_options.text: a philanthropist bought an apartment to allow one couple to remain in their home.
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The sixth paragraph states that when one elderly couple was unable to purchase their apartment, 'a benefactor was approached who bought the apartment on behalf of the resident couple and allowed them to stay on.'

mc_options.text: more artists and creative people wanted to move to the Dakota.
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The passage does not mention that more artists wanted to move to the Dakota after the ownership change.

questions.options:
the residents were able to make huge profits.
investors approached the tenants to buy their apartments.
a philanthropist bought an apartment to allow one couple to remain in their home.
more artists and creative people wanted to move to the Dakota.

questions.question: The Dakota apartments building
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is B. The final paragraph states 'Films, such as the horror 'Rosemary's Baby' in the 1960s, were set at the Dakota, and the Dakota has featured in many New York motion pictures as a landmark building.'

mc_options.text: now only houses famous artists, actors and musicians.
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While famous people have lived there, the passage does not state it only houses them.

mc_options.text: has been used as part of movie sets.
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The final paragraph states 'Films, such as the horror 'Rosemary's Baby' in the 1960s, were set at the Dakota, and the Dakota has featured in many New York motion pictures as a landmark building.'
Incorrect. The passage mentions that Manhattan skyline has more apartment buildings rising up, but does not state the Dakota itself is undergoing development.

mc_options.text: is now the most expensive in New York City.
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While the passage mentions high prices, it does not confirm the Dakota is the most expensive building in New York.

questions.options:
now only houses famous artists, actors and musicians.
has been used as part of movie sets.
is currently undergoing development.
is now the most expensive in New York City.

questions.instructions:
Reading Passage 2 has seven paragraphs A – G.

For paragraphs A – G, choose the most suitable heading from the list of headings below.

Write the appropriate numbers I – X in boxes 14 – 20 on your answer sheet.

NB There are more headings than paragraphs, so some headings will not be used.

List of Headings

i. How terms common today may have arisen
ii. Gender driven preferences
iii. Manipulating the aging process
iv. The components of an appealing pair of jeans
v. Popular culture contributes
vi. Working independently towards a shared goal
vii. Cutting manufacturing costs
viii. A shared vision realized
ix. Researching popular designs of jeans
x. A global commodity

questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is Working independently towards a shared goal. The first paragraph gives information about Levi Strauss and Jacob Davis and how they both were manufacturing, independently of each other, rugged trousers for outdoors workman to wear.

questions.instructions:
Do the following statements agree with the information given in Reading Passage 2?

In boxes 21 – 26 on your answer sheet write

TRUE if the statement agrees with the information
FALSE if the statement contradicts the information
NOT GIVEN if there is no information on this in the passage
questions.question: Levi Strauss initially rejected the idea of using rivets in the new hard-wearing pants.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is NOT GIVEN. There is no information given regarding whether Levi Strauss was initially opposed to using rivets in his jeans manufacturing process.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The passage describes Jacob Davis using rivets and then approaching Strauss for partnership, but does not mention Strauss's initial opinion about rivets.
Incorrect. The passage describes Jacob Davis using rivets and then approaching Strauss for partnership, but does not mention Strauss's initial opinion about rivets.
Correct! The passage does not provide information about Strauss's initial reaction to the rivet idea.

questions.question: Partners, Strauss and Davis, settled immediately on the fabric to be used in their joint manufacturing venture.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is FALSE. Para B states The two men experimented with different fabrics and mentioned that Denim was the material they finally settled on.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Review Paragraph B which states The two men experimented with different fabrics and Denim was the material they finally settled on, indicating it was not an immediate decision.
Correct! Paragraph B clearly states they experimented with different fabrics before finally settling on denim.
Incorrect. Review Paragraph B which states The two men experimented with different fabrics and Denim was the material they finally settled on, indicating it was not an immediate decision.

questions.question: The name denim comes from the Italian language.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is FALSE. Para C states that serge de Nimes was the French name, and this is likely where denim came from.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Review Paragraph C which explains that the term denim is speculated to come from serge de Nimes, a French name, not Italian.
Correct! Paragraph C explains that denim likely came from the French term serge de Nimes, not from Italian.
Incorrect. Review Paragraph C which explains that the term denim is speculated to come from serge de Nimes, a French name, not Italian.

questions.question: More women than men buy Levi zipper-fly jeans.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is NOT GIVEN. Para D states with Levi subsequently introducing the zipper fly in 1947, originally to cater for female tastes but no information is given about subsequent differences in sales by gender.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Although Paragraph D mentions the zipper fly was introduced to cater for female tastes, there is no information about actual sales differences between men and women.
Incorrect. Although Paragraph D mentions the zipper fly was introduced to cater for female tastes, there is no information about actual sales differences between men and women.
Correct! While the passage mentions the zipper fly was introduced to cater for female tastes, it does not provide sales data by gender.

questions.question: Not all innovations relating to jeans manufacture were developed in the U.S.A.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. Para F mentions that a Canadian company introduced the stone-washing technique to soften and fade the jeans.

mc_options.feedback: Correct! Paragraph F states that a Canadian company introduced the stone-washing technique, showing innovation outside the U.S.A.
Incorrect. Review Paragraph F which mentions that a Canadian company, GWG, introduced the stone-washing technique, demonstrating that not all jeans innovations came from the U.S.A.
Incorrect. Review Paragraph F which mentions that a Canadian company, GWG, introduced the stone-washing technique, demonstrating that not all jeans innovations came from the U.S.A.

questions.question: Research shows that Americans own more pairs of jeans than any other type of trousers.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is NOT GIVEN. Para G says that the average American owns seven pairs of jeans but does not say if this is the most popular form of pants/trousers.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Although Paragraph G mentions that the average American owns seven pairs of jeans, it does not indicate whether this is more than any other type of trousers.
Incorrect. Although Paragraph G mentions that the average American owns seven pairs of jeans, it does not indicate whether this is more than any other type of trousers.
Correct! While Paragraph G states Americans own an average of seven pairs of jeans, it does not compare this to ownership of other types of trousers.

questions.instructions:
Do the following statements agree with the information given in Reading Passage 3?

In boxes 27 – 32 on your answer sheet, write

TRUE if the statement agrees with the information

FALSE if the statement contradicts the information

NOT GIVEN if there is no information on this
questions.question: The Tasmanian authorities introduced legislation to protect thylacines in 1935.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is FALSE. The second sentence of Paragraph A states: '…the last captive Tasmanian tiger died in Hobart Zoo on the 7th of September, 1936, less than two months after the Tasmanian government had passed a law to protect the animal.'

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Review Paragraph A which states the last captive Tasmanian tiger died in September 1936, less than two months after the Tasmanian government had passed a law to protect the animal, meaning the law was passed in 1936, not 1935.

Correct! The second sentence of Paragraph A states: '…the last captive Tasmanian tiger died in Hobart Zoo on the 7th of September, 1936, less than two months after the Tasmanian government had passed a law to protect the animal.'

Incorrect. Review Paragraph A which states the last captive Tasmanian tiger died in September 1936, less than two months after the Tasmanian government had passed a law to protect the animal, meaning the law was passed in 1936, not 1935.

questions.question: The Tasmanian tiger is genetically related to the dog family.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is FALSE. Paragraph B states that: 'While the thylacine's body resembles that of members of the dog family, with sharp teeth and powerful jaws, it is, in fact, a true pouched marsupial related to the Tasmanian devil.'

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Review Paragraph B which explains that while the thylacine's body resembles that of the dog family, it is actually a true pouched marsupial related to the Tasmanian devil, not genetically related to dogs.

Correct! Paragraph B states that: 'While the thylacine's body resembles that of members of the dog family, with sharp teeth and powerful jaws, it is, in fact, a true pouched marsupial related to the Tasmanian devil.'

Incorrect. Review Paragraph B which explains that while the thylacine's body resembles that of the dog family, it is actually a true pouched marsupial related to the Tasmanian devil, not genetically related to dogs.

questions.question: Hunting is regarded as the main cause of the extinction of the thylacine in Tasmania.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. Paragraph C states that: 'Popular belief holds that the thylacine's extinction in Tasmania was largely due to the efforts of farmers and bounty hunters killing the animals.'

mc_options.feedback: Correct! Paragraph C states that: 'Popular belief holds that the thylacine's extinction in Tasmania was largely due to the efforts of farmers and bounty hunters killing the animals.'
Incorrect. Review Paragraph C which indicates that popular belief holds that hunting by farmers and bounty hunters was largely responsible for the thylacine's extinction in Tasmania.
Incorrect. Review Paragraph C which indicates that popular belief holds that hunting by farmers and bounty hunters was largely responsible for the thylacine's extinction in Tasmania.

questions.question: Photographs published by the New Scientist were suspected to be fake.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. Paragraph D states that: 'Subsequent examination raised questions about the photographs' authenticity.'

mc_options.feedback: Correct! Paragraph D states that: 'Subsequent examination raised questions about the photographs' authenticity.'
Incorrect. Review Paragraph D which mentions that subsequent examination raised questions about the authenticity of the New Scientist photographs.
Incorrect. Review Paragraph D which mentions that subsequent examination raised questions about the authenticity of the New Scientist photographs.

questions.question: The eyes of foxes shine green at night time.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is NOT GIVEN. While Paragraph E states that 'the colour of dogs' and dingoes' eyes shining in torchlight is green', the colour of foxes' eyes is not mentioned.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While Paragraph E mentions that dogs' and dingoes' eyes shine green in torchlight, there is no information given about what colour foxes' eyes shine, making this NOT GIVEN.
Incorrect. While Paragraph E mentions that dogs' and dingoes' eyes shine green in torchlight, there is no information given about what colour foxes' eyes shine, making this NOT GIVEN.
Correct! While Paragraph E states that 'the colour of dogs' and dingoes' eyes shining in torchlight is green', the colour of foxes' eyes is not mentioned.

questions.question: Bill Laurance puts the chance of finding evidence of living thylacines at less than 3%.
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is TRUE. Paragraph G states that Laurance '…believes that there exists a remote possibility of between one and two percent that the creature could persist in Cape York.'

mc_options.feedback: Correct! Paragraph G states that Laurance '…believes that there exists a remote possibility of between one and two percent that the creature could persist in Cape York.'
Incorrect. Review Paragraph G which states that Bill Laurance believes there is a remote possibility of between 1 and 2 percent, which is indeed less than 3%.
Incorrect. Review Paragraph G which states that Bill Laurance believes there is a remote possibility of between 1 and 2 percent, which is indeed less than 3%.

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 1
reading_texts.content:
Travelling around the country with bus passes

Travel Rider pass
The Travel Rider pass is valid for one month from the day it is purchased and allows travel on any NorWest and Metro Link bus within the city. Photo identification is required to purchase a Travel Rider pass. Prices are £42 for adults, £30 for students and pensioners. Passes can be purchased from any of our branches. Please note that replacement passes can only be issued from the main office in Queen Street.
Flexi-Pass
Flexi-Pass allows travel between cities with an hours-based pass that can be topped up just like a pre paid phone card. With freedom to explore the national network of InterCity Coachlines, you can set your own itinerary and travel around the country, when and where you want. The more hours you buy, the cheaper each trip becomes and you can even use Flexi-Pass on the cross-channel ferry. You have three months to use the hours you purchase, so you don't have to pack too much travelling into a short time frame. The flexi-pass can be purchased from any of our branch offices. Prices:
  • Up to 15 hours – £52
  • 16 to 20 hours – £64
  • 21 to 25 hours – £72
NOTE: No concessions are available on tickets.
Destination Pass
The Destination Pass offers a range of 12 "hop on and off" fixed itinerary passes, based on the most popular touring routes throughout the country. The Destination Pass includes coach and ferry travel, as well as the additional options to sail on Brentwood Lake, all in the one pass. The destination Pass is available through travel agents worldwide or can be purchased through our website. When you're ready to travel, simply call us or log in online to book one of the 12 individual journeys. You can amend your travel plans up to two hours prior to departure without penalty. All trips must be taken within 6 months. Prices:
  • 4 trips – £115
  • 8 trips – £215
  • 12 trips – £390
Student and group (5 people or more) discounts are available. Contact us for more details.

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 2
reading_texts.content:
Gaston Community College evening classes

This semester, the following classes will be available. Class: English for beginners Description: An English language class to help new arrivals to the country learn better English. The course looks at using English in everyday situations, such as shopping, going to the doctors or getting a haircut. Times and days: Mondays and Thursdays at 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 5 – 12 Duration: 6 weeks Fee: £45
Class: Intermediate Spanish Description: This class is ideally suited for students who have a basic knowledge of Spanish or who completed the Beginner's Spanish class held last semester Times and days: Tuesdays and Fridays at 7.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 5-18 Duration: 8 weeks Fee: £55
Class: Using your computer Description: No idea how to use a computer? Then this class if for you! It covers the basics of surfing the internet, sending and receiving emails, typing and understanding files and folders. Times and days: Wednesdays at 6.30 p.m. to 7.15 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 2-8 Duration: 4 weeks Fee: £25
Class: Beginners watercolour painting Description: Back by popular demand and once again run by local artist Ted Heath, this class gives you an opportunity to show your more creative side. NB: you will need to provide your own paper, paint and brushes Thursdays from 7.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 4-12 Duration: 8 weeks Fee: £40
Class: Better public speaking Description: For all those who have completed public speaking or presentation skills courses, or who have some experience and wish to brush up on their skills. Practise connecting with your audience and communicating your message with full effectiveness. Times and days: Tuesdays 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. and Wednesdays at 7.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 2-8 Duration: 4 weeks Fee: £30
Class: Successful interview techniques Description: Many courses focus on presenting yourself well at an interview, but this course will help you become a better interviewer – ideal for those perhaps run a small business and would like to be sure they are recruiting the right person. We will cover preparation, body language and good interview questions. Times and days: Mondays and Fridays at 7.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 4-10 Duration: 5 weeks Fee: £35
Class: Authentic Thai cooking Description: Learn to cook Thai food the fun way with a native, experienced chef. A hands-on and demonstration course covering exciting dishes from all regions of Thailand. Aspects of Thai culture will be covered and all recipes and ingredients supplied. Times and days: Tuesdays from 7.00 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 4-10 Duration: 8 weeks Fee: £35 + £55 food costs
Class: Beginners guitar Description: Learn to play both classical and popular techniques. Please bring your own guitar, and a music stand and floor step if you have one. You will need to buy a textbook. Even if you've never played a note before, you should be able to play a tune by the end of the course. Times and days: Wednesdays from 7.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 2-6 Duration: 5 weeks Fee: £20
Class: Digital photos Description: A fun & practical workshop just for digital camera users. Learn how to use the main functions of your camera. Lots of practice with portraits, action shots, night scenes & landscapes. Learn different ways to transfer your photos on to the computer – emailing, printing, resizing photos, changing colour or contrast, convert colour to black & white. Times and days: Mondays 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. and Wednesdays at 7.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. Minimum-maximum class sizes: 4-10 Duration: 6 weeks Fee: £40

ESITO dress code

The personal appearance of office workers and employees who have regular contact with the public is laid out in the company dress code. In brief, the code requires all employees to observe the following:
  • Clean, pressed, properly fitting business casual attire is appropriate.
  • Hair should be clean, combed and neatly arranged. Long hair is acceptable if it is tied back.
  • Moustaches and beards should be neatly trimmed.
  • Good personal hygiene must be maintained.
  • Use perfume or cologne in small quantities or not at all (some people are allergic to various scents).
The personal appearance of employees who do not regularly meet the public is to be decided by the requirements of safety, comfort and supervisor approval. Even so, because all employees are a representative of the company, they should be as neat and business-like as working conditions permit. The following are some examples of inappropriate dress at all times:
  • Faded and/or tattered/torn jeans; t-shirts displaying advertising or writing
  • Faded overalls, cotton/fleece pants and jogging suits, shorts, tank tops or recreational attire
  • Clothing revealing bare backs, midriffs or shoulders; or any revealing clothing.
Casual Fridays: The Company has designated Fridays as casual days. Some clothing is still considered inappropriate even on casual days. Employees are requested to use good sense in this regard. Bad weather days: The Company understands that inclement weather conditions can require different attire for the day. Use good judgment when dressing for weather conditions. NOTE: This only impacts on employees working in the yard. The supervisor is responsible for evaluating the dress and appearance of employees under his or her supervision. If an employee is not dressed appropriately, the supervisor should take the following steps: On the first occasion, a documented verbal warning should be given to the employee, and the department's dress and appearance standards should be reviewed. If the supervisor deems it necessary, the employee may be sent home to change into appropriate clothing. On the second occasion, the employee must be sent home to change clothes immediately as well as given a written warning. Further violations may result in discipline up to and including discharge.

Benefits and amendment to benefits for Glyph Interactive employees

Pension scheme

All employees are automatically included in our pension scheme, although there is an 'opt out' policy for employees with private pension plans. The pension scheme is no longer non-contributory, with employees now being asked to pay 25% of the annual payment. Government contributions will amount to an additional 25%, with Glyph Interactive continuing to support employees by covering the remaining 50%. Employees need to pay into the pension scheme for a minimum of 20 years. Once an employee reaches the age of 65, the pension payments begin. Employees who do not reach the twenty year mark will be paid pro rata (that is, an employee who has worked only ten years will receive only 50% of that received by an employee with twenty years experience).

Medical insurance

Due to rising costs, we can no longer support offering medical insurance to retiring employees. Standard cover still applies to all active employees, with one important addition. The immediate family (spouse and children) of the employee can also be covered for the same benefits and services. This will attract an additional payment depending on the current health of those wishing to be covered, but will be well below the cost of seeking insurance with a private company.

Access to company vehicles

All staff with a legitimate need to travel will have access to one of the company vehicles. Please note that this is to be used for company purposes only, and must be applied for in writing at least two days before the vehicle is needed. For urgent and unexpected requirements, please consult your manager. The only exception to this is for sales staff, who have already been issued their own vehicles.

Communication

All members of staff have a laptop which is issued on the first day of employment. This will now be supplemented by the addition of a Smartphone. Please note, however, that all calls and communications using the Smartphone should be for company purposes only unless in an emergency. Training events will be posted in the next few weeks to help you get to grips with the new phone.

Working from home

We are now in the second year of the trial of some employees working from home for at least a part of the week. Despite some earlier difficulties, the scheme has proven successful and will now be offered as an option for all staff (although final approval must be given by your manager).

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 3
reading_texts.content:
Reading Passage 3

You should spend about 20 minutes on Questions 27 – 40 which are based on Reading Passage 3.

The Tasmanian Tiger

Is the extinct marsupial still roaming the Australian mainland?

A: Once found throughout continental Australia, as well as the islands of Tasmania and New Guinea, the large, carnivorous marsupial species commonly called the Tasmanian tiger or Tasmanian wolf, is believed to have become extinct in the 1930s. At one time the world's largest marsupial predator, the last captive Tasmanian tiger died in Hobart Zoo on the 7th of September, 1936, less than two months after the Tasmanian government had passed a law to protect the animal. However, since that time, there have been hundreds of reported sightings of the Tasmanian tiger in remote locations both on the Australian mainland and in Tasmania. In addition to eyewitness accounts, a number of sightings are supported by photographs and video footage of the animal, although this evidence is considered inconclusive. The thylacine, as the Tasmanian tiger is formally known, continues to be regarded as an extinct species by the scientific community.

B: The Tasmanian tiger's scientific or binomial name, Thylacinus cynocephalus, means "pouched and dog-headed". In terms of its physical appearance, the thylacine is described as being a large, shorthaired, doglike animal, with yellow-brown fur, and dark, vertical stripes running down its lower back to the base of the tail, similar to those of a tiger. Its stripy coat earned the thylacine the nickname of Tasmanian tiger. While the thylacine's body resembles that of members of the dog family, with sharp teeth and powerful jaws, it is, in fact, a true pouched marsupial related to the Tasmanian devil. It is thought that the Tasmanian tiger was predominantly quadrupedal, routinely walking on all fours, although captive animals were also observed as being able to stand on their hind legs and hop like a kangaroo.

C: Experts believe that the thylacine most likely became extinct in mainland Australia and New Guinea around 2000 years ago, largely as a result of competition for food with indigenous people and their introduced wild dogs, known as dingoes. At the same time, it has been theorised that a lack of genetic diversity in the thylacine population, due to physical isolation, may have been another cause. As far as the fate of the species on the island state of Tasmania is concerned, a number of reasons have been put forward to explain its decline and subsequent extinction. These include competition with dogs introduced by European settlers, the loss of prey species and natural habitat, disease and hunting. For more than a century, both the Van Diemen's Land Company and the Tasmanian government offered financial rewards, or bounties, on thylacines that were killed, with a view to controlling their numbers to reduce attacks on sheep by Tasmanian tigers. Popular belief holds that the thylacine's extinction in Tasmania was largely due to the efforts of farmers and bounty hunters killing the animals.

D: Despite the fact that most scientists consider the Tasmanian tiger to be extinct, each year dozens of unconfirmed sightings of the animal are reported from relatively uninhabited areas in New Guinea, Tasmania and mainland Australia by people from all walks of life. However, to date, there has been no conclusive physical evidence of a living thylacine population in any of these locations. On 24 April 1986, the New Scientist magazine made world news when it published a series of colour photographs of an alleged Tasmanian tiger taken by Kevin Cameron, an expert tracker employed with the Agricultural Protection Board of Western Australia. The pictures showed a grey animal with fawn stripes, partly hidden from view in wilderness surrounds. Subsequent examination raised questions about the photographs' authenticity.

E: Recently, the British daily newspaper The Guardian, along with other media publications, ran a story detailing the plans of a group of scientists from James Cook University to undertake a search for the Tasmanian tiger on the remote Cape York Peninsula in Queensland's far north. The expedition was prompted by a pair of detailed sightings, one from a long-time employee of the Queensland National Parks Service, that appear to be both credible and plausible. While the vast majority of thylacine sightings are dismissed as cases of mistaken identity, where eyewitnesses are said to have seen foxes, dingoes or feral dogs, the Cape York accounts differ in one key detail. Both observers reported that the animals' eyes shone red at night, whereas the colour of dogs' and dingoes' eyes shining in torchlight is green. In addition, the size, shape and behaviour of the creatures, as described by the Cape York eyewitnesses, were not consistent with those of other large species found in north Queensland.

F: The two James Cook University researchers undertaking the Cape York expedition, Professor Bill Laurance and Doctor Sandra Abell, have stated that they will set up more than fifty trail cameras in the area of the sightings, one to two kilometres apart, in the hopes of photographing a live Tasmanian tiger. Isolated, uninhabited and not very extensively explored, the Cape York Peninsula in Australia's northeast is known to be home to a number of endangered species that are not found anywhere else on the continent. The traps will be baited with a scent that is attractive to predatory species, and the research team plan to check the cameras every few weeks and download the data, with a view to gathering photographic evidence of living thylacines.

G: While Laurance admits that the chance of rediscovering the Tasmanian tiger alive in north Queensland is very slim, given that it is unlikely that the species could survive in such low numbers, he believes that there exists a remote possibility of between 1 and 2% that the creature could persist in Cape York. Jack Ashby, manager of the Grant Museum of Zoology at University College London, shares this view. "It's not impossible", he says.
